Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Situation2: They occasionally offer comforting words to someone in their congregation who seems troubled.
Story: I sat across from Mia at our favorite café, her fingers laced with mine, her eyes searching my face for reassurance. It was our last weekend together before she left for her new job overseas, and I could feel the weight of every moment pressing down on us. I wanted to give her all my attention, to make these hours count, to show her how much she meant to me. My phone buzzed on the table, and I glanced at the screen. It was a message from Mark, a member of my congregation. He’d been struggling lately, and now he was reaching out, asking if I had time to talk. I knew he wouldn’t ask unless he really needed it. My heart twisted. Mia squeezed my hand, sensing my distraction. I could see the hope in her eyes—that I would choose her, just this once, over everyone else. But I could also hear the silent plea in Mark’s message, the expectation that I would be there for him as his pastor. I stared at my phone, torn between the woman I loved and the calling I’d promised to honor, feeling the impossible pull of both worlds.
